elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of Zn(NO3)2 with tetrakis(4-pyridyl)­cyclobutane (tpcb) and 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2ndc) and 2,3-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,3-H2ndc) in different solvents led to the formation of three polydimensional coordination polymers {[Zn2(H2O)­(1,4-ndc)2(tpcb)]} n (1), {[Zn(1,4-ndc)­(tpcb)0.5]} n (2), and {[Zn2(H2O)­(2,3-ndc)2(tpcb)]} n (3). Compounds 1–3 were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 is a three-dimensional (3D) (3,3)-connected net with a (10·122)·(102·12) Schläfli symbol. Compound 2 holds a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D framework with a (42·62·72)·(4·62·73) Schläfli symbol, which shows hexagonal-prism-like one-dimensional channels. Compound 3 shows a two-dimensional (3,8)-connected network. The solid state luminescent, optical, and thermal stability properties of 1–3 at ambient temperature were also investigated. A comparative study on their photocatalytic activity toward the degradation of methyl orange and methyl blue in polluted water was explored. The results provided some interesting insights into solvent effects on the structures of zinc(II) coordination polymers and their photocatalytic applications.

The results provided some interesting insights into solvent effects on the structures of zinc(II) coordination polymers and their photocatalytic applications.

elements.content: In recent years, the increasing attention on functional coordination polymers has led to the fast development of this type of solid material. Because of their fascinating topologies and potential applications in catalysis, adsorption, separation, magnetism, and luminescence, rational design and synthesis of specific structures with desired properties seem particularly important. However, it still remains a challenging task as many delicate factors such as organic linkers, temperatures, pH values, and solvents may greatly influence the final structures of coordination polymers. On the other hand, how to photocatalytically decompose organic dyes in polluted water in an efficient way remains a tough job because of the challenges of the environment and development of green chemistry. One possible way is to employ various coordination polymers as photocatalysis, a few of which have been documented recently. To this end, it would be of importance to prepare coordination polymers with different structures and explore their photocatalytic performances in degrading organic dyes in polluted water.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, the increasing attention on functional coordination polymers has led to the fast development of this type of solid material. Because of their fascinating topologies and potential applications in catalysis, adsorption, separation, magnetism, and luminescence, rational design and synthesis of specific structures with desired properties seem particularly important. However, it still remains a challenging task as many delicate factors such as organic linkers, temperatures, pH values, and solvents may greatly influence the final structures of coordination polymers. On the other hand, how to photocatalytically decompose organic dyes in polluted water in an efficient way remains a tough job because of the challenges of the environment and development of green chemistry. One possible way is to employ various coordination polymers as photocatalysis, a few of which have been documented recently. To this end, it would be of importance to prepare coordination polymers with different structures and explore their photocatalytic performances in degrading organic dyes in polluted water.

elements.content: Currently, the most common method to prepare coordination polymers is to run reactions of metal salts with N-donor and/or O-donor ligands. In the case of N-donor ligands, tetrakis(4-pyridyl)­cyclobutane (tpcb) is an excellent multidentate N-donor ligand in which four pyridyl groups may have different conformations around the cyclobutyl ring when it combines with metal ions. We have recently been involved in the synthesis, structures, and functionalities of coordination polymers derived from the tpcb ligand and dicarboxylate ligands. For example, we employed tpcb to combine Ni(II) and 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate (1,3-bdc), forming an interesting three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymer [Ni2(μ-OH2)­(1,3-BDC)2(tpcb)] n , which had a stable framework void to separate a solid mixture of naphthalene and anthracene at ambient temperature via selective adsorption of naphthalene. However, we chose tpcb to react with Cd(II) and 1,3-bdc, and isolated a totally different coordination polymer [Cd(tpcb)0.5(1,3-bdc)] n , which has a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D net. Could reactions of other metal ions with tpcb and dicarboxylates afford new polydimensional frameworks? Could the resulting coordination polymers with tpcb and dicarboxylates be used as efficient photocatalysts for decomposing organic dyes in polluted water? With these questions in mind, we deliberately selected Zn(NO3)2 as the metal salt and carried out its reactions with 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-ndc) or 2,3-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,3-ndc) (Scheme ) and tpcb under the solvothermal conditions. Three novel Zn(II)/tpcb/dicarboxylate two-dimensional (2D) and 3D coordination polymers {[Zn2(H2O)­(1,4-ndc)2(tpcb)]} n (1), {[Zn(1,4-ndc)­(tpcb)0.5]} n (2), and {[Zn2(H2O)­(2,3-ndc)2(tpcb)]} n (3) were isolated and structurally characterized. Compounds 1–3 did exhibit good catalytic activity toward photocatalytic decomposition of methyl orange and methyl blue in contaminated water. Herein we report their syntheses, crystal structures, luminescent, and optical and photocatalytic performances.

elements.content: Solvothermal reaction of a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, tpcb, 1,4-H2ndc (molar ratio 1:1:1) in H2O and DMF (v/v = 5/1) at 150 °C in a sealed Pyrex glass tube for 1 day afforded yellow blocks of 1 in 22% yield. Similar reactions of the same components with the same molar ratio in H2O and MeCN (v/v = 5/1) at 150 °C generated yellow crystals of 2 in 51% yield. We also carried out reactions of these three components in other solvents such as H2O/MeOH, H2O/EtOH, which only yielded a large amount of insoluble precipitate. Analogous reactions were carried out at higher temperatures (e.g., 160 °C) or lower temperatures (e.g., 130 °C), which gave rise to the same products in relatively lower yields. We also attempted to adjust the pH values (from 4 to 10), but no good-quality crystals of the same products were observed. In addition, after heating 1 at 100 °C for 6 h, the yellow crystals of 1 were turned into a white powder, which was analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (), and its patterns were totally different from those of 1 or 2 (). This result suggested that 1 could not be transformed into 2 after the removal of the coordinated waters of 1. Similar reactions starting from 2,3-ndc instead of 1,4-ndc in H2O and MeCN (v/v = 5/1) at 150 °C gave rise to yellow cubic crystals of 3 in 32% yield. Reactions of the same components at higher temperatures (e.g., 160 °C) or lower temperatures (e.g., 130 °C) gave the same product of 3, while in other solvent systems such as H2O and DMF (v/v = 5/1), we could not isolate any useful products. The different outcomes of these reactions may be due to the so-called solvent effects, which have been observed in many documented examples.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthetic and Spectral Aspects

Solvothermal reaction of a mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, tpcb, 1,4-H2ndc (molar ratio 1:1:1) in H2O and DMF (v/v = 5/1) at 150 °C in a sealed Pyrex glass tube for 1 day afforded yellow blocks of 1 in 22% yield. Similar reactions of the same components with the same molar ratio in H2O and MeCN (v/v = 5/1) at 150 °C generated yellow crystals of 2 in 51% yield. We also carried out reactions of these three components in other solvents such as H2O/MeOH, H2O/EtOH, which only yielded a large amount of insoluble precipitate. Analogous reactions were carried out at higher temperatures (e.g., 160 °C) or lower temperatures (e.g., 130 °C), which gave rise to the same products in relatively lower yields. We also attempted to adjust the pH values (from 4 to 10), but no good-quality crystals of the same products were observed. In addition, after heating 1 at 100 °C for 6 h, the yellow crystals of 1 were turned into a white powder, which was analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (), and its patterns were totally different from those of 1 or 2 (). This result suggested that 1 could not be transformed into 2 after the removal of the coordinated waters of 1. Similar reactions starting from 2,3-ndc instead of 1,4-ndc in H2O and MeCN (v/v = 5/1) at 150 °C gave rise to yellow cubic crystals of 3 in 32% yield. Reactions of the same components at higher temperatures (e.g., 160 °C) or lower temperatures (e.g., 130 °C) gave the same product of 3, while in other solvent systems such as H2O and DMF (v/v = 5/1), we could not isolate any useful products. The different outcomes of these reactions may be due to the so-called solvent effects, which have been observed in many documented examples.

elements.content: Compounds 1–3 are air and moisture stable and insoluble in common organic solvents such as CHCl3, MeCN, and DMF and DMSO. The elemental analyses were consistent with their chemical formula. In the IR spectra of 1–3, the strong bonds at 1612–1622 cm–1 and 1355–1363 cm–1 represent the coordinated carboxyl groups. For 1–3, the PXRD showed that the observed patterns for each compound correlate well with the simulated ones generated from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (), suggesting the bulk phase homogeneity of the three complexes. The identities of 1–3 were finally confirmed by X-ray crystallography.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c, and its asymmetric unit contains one [Zn2(H2O)­(1,4-ndc)2(tpcb)] molecule. In 1, each Zn1 atom adopts a very distorted trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry, chelated by two O atoms from a 1,4-ndc ligand and coordinated by two N atoms from two tpcb ligands and one O atom from a coordinated water molecule (Figure a). The mean Zn–N bond length (2.049(4) Å) (Table ) is similar to that of [Zn(1,3,5-HBTC)­(1,4-bpeb)] n (1,3,5-BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, 1,4-bpeb = 1,4-bis[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzene) (2.045(2) Å), while the average Zn–O(1,4-ndc) bond length (2.159(3) Å) is longer than the corresponding one in [Zn(1,3,5-HBTC)­(1,4-bpeb)] n (2.040(2) Å). The Zn–O(H2O) bond length (1.997(3) Å) is slightly shorter than that of [Zn(OH2)(5-HO-1,3-BDC)­(1,4-bpeb)] n (5-HO-1,3-BDC = 5-hydroxy-1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) (2.020(2) Å). As shown in Figure b, Zn2 is tetrahedrally coordinated by three O atoms from three 1,4-ndc ligands and one N atom from a tpcb ligand. For Zn2, the mean Zn–O and Zn–N bond lengths (1.985(3) Å vs 2.058(4) Å) are comparable to those of {[Zn5(1,4-bdc)5(tpcb)2.5]·5H2O} n (1,4-bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) (1.934(5) Å vs 2.035(5)). The four pyridyl groups of each tpcb ligand in 1 adopt an up–down–up–down conformation as shown in Scheme with the dihedral angle between the two opposite pyridyl groups being 51.94° and 42.62°. In 1, the two carboxyl groups of the 1,4-ndc ligands exhibit two different coordination modes: monodentate/monodentate (Scheme a) and monodentate/chelating (Scheme b). Two opposite pyridyl groups in one tpcb ligand link the five-coordinated Zn(II) centers to form a [Zn2(tpcb)] n chain extending along the c axis (Figure c). The third pyridyl group in the tpcb ligand connects with the tetrahedrally coordinated Zn(II) center. The fourth pyridyl group of each tpcb retains intact, which makes the tpcb ligand working as a unique three-connecting linker. Such a one-dimensional (1D) [Zn2(tpcb)] n chain is connected by 1,4-ndc ligands with the monodentate/chelating mode (Scheme b) to its neighboring ones to give a 2D wavy network (Figure d). The 1,4-ndc ligands with the monodentate/monodentate mode (Scheme a) further connect the 2D layer to its equivalent ones, therefore forming a unique 3D framework (Figure e). Topologically, if the 1,4-ndc ligands, Zn(II) centers and tpcb ligands are viewed as three-connecting nodes, the framework of 1 can be simplified to a (10·122)·(102·12) net (). Such two independent equivalent nets further interpenetrate, generating a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure f).

The mean Zn-N bond length (2.049(4) Å) (Table ) is similar to that of [Zn(1,3,5-HBTC)(1,4-bpeb)] n  (1,3,5-BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, 1,4-bpeb = 1,4-bis[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzene) (2.045(2) Å), while the average Zn-O(1,4-ndc) bond length (2.159(3) Å) is longer than the corresponding one in [Zn(1,3,5-HBTC)(1,4-bpeb)] n  (2.040(2) Å). The Zn-O(H2O) bond length (1.997(3) Å) is slightly shorter than that of [Zn(OH2)(5-HO-1,3-BDC)(1,4-bpeb)] n  (5-HO-1,3-BDC = 5-hydroxy-1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) (2.020(2) Å). As shown in Figure b, Zn2 is tetrahedrally coordinated by three O atoms from three 1,4-ndc ligands and one N atom from a tpcb ligand. For Zn2, the mean Zn-O and Zn-N bond lengths (1.985(3) Å vs 2.058(4) Å) are comparable to those of {[Zn5(1,4-bdc)5(tpcb)2.5]⋅5H2O} n  (1,4-bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) (1.934(5) Å vs 2.035(5)). The four pyridyl groups of each tpcb ligand in 1 adopt an up-down-up-down conformation as shown in Scheme  with the dihedral angle between the two opposite pyridyl groups being 51.94° and 42.62°. In 1, the two carboxyl groups of the 1,4-ndc ligands exhibit two different coordination modes: monodentate/monodentate (Scheme a) and monodentate/chelating (Scheme b). Two opposite pyridyl groups in one tpcb ligand link the five-coordinated Zn(II) centers to form a [Zn2(tpcb)] n  chain extending along the c axis (Figure c). The third pyridyl group in the tpcb ligand connects with the tetrahedrally coordinated Zn(II) center. The fourth pyridyl group of each tpcb retains intact, which makes the tpcb ligand working as a unique three-connecting linker. Such a one-dimensional (1D) [Zn2(tpcb)] n  chain is connected by 1,4-ndc ligands with the monodentate/chelating mode (Scheme b) to its neighboring ones to give a 2D wavy network (Figure d). The 1,4-ndc ligands with the monodentate/monodentate mode (Scheme a) further connect the 2D layer to its equivalent ones, therefore forming a unique 3D framework (Figure e). Topologically, if the 1,4-ndc ligands, Zn(II) centers and tpcb ligands are viewed as three-connecting nodes, the framework of 1 can be simplified to a (10⋅122)⋅(102⋅12) net (). Such two independent equivalent nets further interpenetrate, generating a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure f).

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the hexagonal space group P6122 and its asymmetric unit consists of one [Zn(1,4-ndc)(tpcb)0.5] molecule. In 2, both Zn1 and Zn2 centers exhibit a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, coordinated by four O atoms from two 1,4-ndc ligands and two N atoms from two tpcb ligands (Figure a,b). The average Zn–O bond length (2.186(3) Å) (Table ) in 2 is longer than those of the corresponding ones of [{(OAc)(μ-OAc)Zn}2­(μ-bpe)2] n (2.007(14) Å), bpe = 1,2-bipyridylethane) and [Zn2(μ-bpf)2­(μ-OAc)2(OAc)2] (2.026(13) Å, bpf = 1,10-bis(4-pyridyl)ferrocene), while the mean Zn–N bond length (2.118(3) Å) is shorter than those found in [{(OAc)(μ-OAc)­Zn}2(μ-bpe)2] n (2.200(3) Å) and [Zn2(μ-bpf)2­(μ-OAc)2(OAc)2] (2.177(3) Å). The four pyridyl groups of each tpcb ligand in 2 take a conformation similar to that of 1 with the dihedral angle between the two opposite pyridyl groups being 48.10° and 82.45°. The two carboxyl groups in each 1,4-ndc ligand serve as the chelating/chelating coordination mode (Scheme c). Each Zn(II) center is bridged by two 1,4-ndc ligands to form a 1D [Zn(1,4-ndc)] n chain extending along the b axis (Figure c). Viewing along the a axis, such a chain is linked via pairs of the tpcb ligands to its equivalent ones, thus giving a 3D net (Figure d). Its interpenetration with the other equivalent net generates a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure e). The whole framework has hexagonal-prism-like 1D channels extending along the b axis, and the effective solvent accessible volume is 3614.9 Å3 per unit cell (40.9% of the total cell volume calculated by the Platon program). If the Zn(II) center and tpcb ligand are considered as four-connecting nodes, the whole structure of 2 can be described as a 4-connected 2-fold interpenetrating 3D net with a (42·62·72)·(4·62·73) Schläfli symbol (Figure f and ).

Crystal Structure of {[Zn(1,4-ndc)(tpcb)0.5]} n  (2)

Compound 2 crystallizes in the hexagonal space group P6122 and its asymmetric unit consists of one [Zn(1,4-ndc)(tpcb)0.5] molecule. In 2, both Zn1 and Zn2 centers exhibit a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, coordinated by four O atoms from two 1,4-ndc ligands and two N atoms from two tpcb ligands (Figure a,b). The average Zn-O bond length (2.186(3) Å) (Table ) in 2 is longer than those of the corresponding ones of [{(OAc)(μ-OAc)Zn}2(μ-bpe)2] n  (2.007(14) Å), bpe = 1,2-bipyridylethane) and [Zn2(μ-bpf)2(μ-OAc)2(OAc)2] (2.026(13) Å, bpf = 1,10-bis(4-pyridyl)ferrocene), while the mean Zn-N bond length (2.118(3) Å) is shorter than those found in [{(OAc)(μ-OAc)Zn}2(μ-bpe)2] n  (2.200(3) Å) and [Zn2(μ-bpf)2(μ-OAc)2(OAc)2] (2.177(3) Å). The four pyridyl groups of each tpcb ligand in 2 take a conformation similar to that of 1 with the dihedral angle between the two opposite pyridyl groups being 48.10° and 82.45°. The two carboxyl groups in each 1,4-ndc ligand serve as the chelating/chelating coordination mode (Scheme c). Each Zn(II) center is bridged by two 1,4-ndc ligands to form a 1D [Zn(1,4-ndc)] n  chain extending along the b axis (Figure c). Viewing along the a axis, such a chain is linked via pairs of the tpcb ligands to its equivalent ones, thus giving a 3D net (Figure d). Its interpenetration with the other equivalent net generates a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure e). The whole framework has hexagonal-prism-like 1D channels extending along the b axis, and the effective solvent accessible volume is 3614.9 Å3 per unit cell (40.9% of the total cell volume calculated by the Platon program). If the Zn(II) center and tpcb ligand are considered as four-connecting nodes, the whole structure of 2 can be described as a 4-connected 2-fold interpenetrating 3D net with a (42⋅62⋅72)⋅(4⋅62⋅73) Schläfli symbol (Figure f and ).

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the same monoclinic space group P21/n and its asymmetric unit contains half a [Zn2(H2O)­(2,3-ndc)2(tpcb)] unit. In 3, Zn1 is tetrahedrally coordinated by three O atoms from three 2,3-ndc ligands and one N atom from a tpcb ligand (Figure a), while Zn2 adopts an octahedral coordination constructed by three O atoms from two 2,3-ndc ligands, two N atoms from two tpcb ligands and one O atom from a coordinated water molecule (Figure b). For Zn1, the average Zn–N bond length (2.046(5) Å) (Table ) is comparable to that of the corresponding one of 1, while the Zn–O bond length (1.952(4) Å) is shorter than that of 1. For Zn2, the mean Zn–N bond length (2.134(4) Å) is slightly longer than that of the corresponding one in 2, while the average Zn–O(ndc) length (2.077(4) Å) is shorter than the corresponding one in 2, and the Zn–O(H2O) bond length (2.417(5) Å) is longer than that found in 1. Each tpcb ligand adopts a comformation similar to that of 1 with the dihedral angle between two opposite pyridyl groups being 53.51° and 73.96°. The two carboxyl groups of the 2,3-ndc ligands in 3 show two different coordination modes: monodentate/monodentate (Scheme d) and η,η-μ-bridging/η,η-μ-bridging (Scheme e). Four Zn(II) centers are bridged by 2,3-ndc linkers to generate a tetranuclear [Zn4(2,3-ndc)6] unit (Figure c). These units are further interlinked by 2,3-ndc bridges, forming a 2D [Zn(2,3-ndc)] n layer extending along the bc plane (Figure d). Each tpcb ligand acts as a tridentate bridge to combine three Zn(II) centers above and below the 2D layer (Figure e). Intermolecular H–O···H hydrogen bonding interactions (2.007 Å) exist between the H(H2O) atom and O(COO–) atom (). If the tetranuclear [Zn4(2,3-ndc)6] unit and the tpcb ligand are regarded as eight-connecting node and three-connecting node, respectively, the whole structure of 3 can be simplied into a (3,8)-connected 2D network (Figure f).

elements.content: The thermal stability of 1–3 was studied by the thermogravimetric differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) technique. The thermogravimetric analyses revealed that 1–3 were stable up to 353 °C (1), 352 °C (2), and 357 °C (3) (). For 1 and 3, the first weight loss of 1.90% from 25 to 81 °C (1) or 2.01% from 25 to 46 °C (3) corresponds roughly to the loss of one coordinated water molecule per formula unit in 1 and 3 (both calculated 1.91%). The second weight loss of 78.65% from 353 to 435 °C (1) or 79.53% from 357 to 424 °C (3) approximately amounts to the loss of all tpcb and naphthalenedicarboxylate ligands (both calculated 80.88%). For 2, only one weight loss of 82.45% from 357 to 615 °C amounts roughly to the loss of tpcb and 1,4-ndc ligands (calculated 82.42%). In all cases, the decomposition residue species, according to X-ray fluorescence analysis, was assumed to be ZnO (19.45% vs calculated 17.36% (1), 17.55% vs calculated 17.53% (2), and 18.46% vs calculated 17.36% (3)).

Thermal and Photoluminescent Properties

The thermal stability of 1-3 was studied by the thermogravimetric differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) technique. The thermogravimetric analyses revealed that 1-3 were stable up to 353 °C (1), 352 °C (2), and 357 °C (3) (). For 1 and 3, the first weight loss of 1.90% from 25 to 81 °C (1) or 2.01% from 25 to 46 °C (3) corresponds roughly to the loss of one coordinated water molecule per formula unit in 1 and 3 (both calculated 1.91%). The second weight loss of 78.65% from 353 to 435 °C (1) or 79.53% from 357 to 424 °C (3) approximately amounts to the loss of all tpcb and naphthalenedicarboxylate ligands (both calculated 80.88%). For 2, only one weight loss of 82.45% from 357 to 615 °C amounts roughly to the loss of tpcb and 1,4-ndc ligands (calculated 82.42%). In all cases, the decomposition residue species, according to X-ray fluorescence analysis, was assumed to be ZnO (19.45% vs calculated 17.36% (1), 17.55% vs calculated 17.53% (2), and 18.46% vs calculated 17.36% (3)).

elements.content: The photoluminescent properties of 1–3 in the solid state were studied at room temperature (Figure ). Upon excitation at 300 nm (1 and 2) and 370 nm (3), 1–3 exhibited photoluminescence with emission maxima at 450 nm (1), 410 nm (2), and 460 nm, respectively. The maximum emission wavelength for tpcb (λex = 330 nm) appears at 428 nm. Thus the emission maxima of 1 and 3 are slightly blue-shifted, which may be tentatively assigned to the π–π* intraligand fluorescence due to their close resemblance to the emission band of the tpcb ligand. Intriguingly, relative to that of the tpcb ligand, the emission peak of 2 is red-shifted ligand, which may be ascribed to the charge-transfer transitions between the coordinated ligands and the Zn(II) centers.

elements.content: The optical diffuse-reflection spectra of crystalline solids 1–3 were measured at room temperature. The absorption (α/S) data were calculated from the reflectance using the Kubelka–Munk function: α / S = ( 1 − R ) 2 2 R where α is the absorption, S is the scattering coefficient, and R is the reflectance at a given energy. The energy band gaps (E onset) obtained by extrapolation of the linear portion of the absorption edges were estimated to be 2.62 eV (1), 2.90 eV (2), and 3.34 eV (3) (Figure ). These band gap values suggested that 1–3 may response to UV light and possess the potential capacity for photocatalytic reactions.

elements.content: The photocatalytic activities of 1–3 were evaluated by the degradation of methyl orange (MO) and methyl blue (MB) in aqueous solution. As a chemically stable and poorly biodegradable dye, MO and MB are two main dyes in wastewater of the textile industry. In this work, we employed their photodegradation as a model route to demonstrate the photocatalytic activities of 1–3 in the purification of contaminated water. The decomposition of MO or MB was monitored by the characteristic absorption band at 460 nm for MO or 600 nm for MB. When no catalyst was added to the system, the degradation of MO was negligible. In fact, MO could be slightly decomposed even after irradiation under UV light for a long time (), while MB was relatively active and could be degraded by 50% after 10 h (). Figure shows a comparison of the photocatalytic activities of 1–3. For 1, the degradation of MO or MB was finished after almost 24 h, indicating a relatively low activity for the photocatalytic reaction (). In comparison, compound 2 showed a higher capacity than 1, and the full degradation time for MO and MB was 14 and 10 h, respectively (). No obvious decrease of characteristic absorption was found after two days when placing 2 in MO and MB aqueous solution in the dark, which may avoid the possibility of adsorption. The photocatalytic reaction for the decomposition of MO and MB initiated by 3 was faster than those catalyzed by 1 and 2. The MO and MB completely decomposed upon UV light irradiation for 10 and 8 h (). As shown in Figure b, the absorbance of MB decreased immediately after reaction (∼30 min), but the rate for decomposition was almost similar after prolonged irradiation. This observance was consistent with those reported in the literature, in which the rate for the decomposition of MB was reported to be fast in the beginning and then slow in later time. Thus the absorbance of MB onto the coordination polymers could be ruled out. It is noted that the pure tpcb, 1,4-H2ndc, and 2,3-H2ndc ligands had no evident photocatalytic activity and only caused a slight fading of the MO or MB solution, which may be due to the self-degradation mentioned above. The final colorless solution was extracted by acetic ether, and the organic phase was analyzed by gas-chromatography (GC). No organic species was observed, and thus we could assume that all the dyes were converted into CO2 and H2O.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Properties

The photocatalytic activities of 1-3 were evaluated by the degradation of methyl orange (MO) and methyl blue (MB) in aqueous solution. As a chemically stable and poorly biodegradable dye, MO and MB are two main dyes in wastewater of the textile industry. In this work, we employed their photodegradation as a model route to demonstrate the photocatalytic activities of 1-3 in the purification of contaminated water. The decomposition of MO or MB was monitored by the characteristic absorption band at 460 nm for MO or 600 nm for MB. When no catalyst was added to the system, the degradation of MO was negligible. In fact, MO could be slightly decomposed even after irradiation under UV light for a long time (), while MB was relatively active and could be degraded by 50% after 10 h (). Figure  shows a comparison of the photocatalytic activities of 1-3. For 1, the degradation of MO or MB was finished after almost 24 h, indicating a relatively low activity for the photocatalytic reaction (). In comparison, compound 2 showed a higher capacity than 1, and the full degradation time for MO and MB was 14 and 10 h, respectively (). No obvious decrease of characteristic absorption was found after two days when placing 2 in MO and MB aqueous solution in the dark, which may avoid the possibility of adsorption. The photocatalytic reaction for the decomposition of MO and MB initiated by 3 was faster than those catalyzed by 1 and 2. The MO and MB completely decomposed upon UV light irradiation for 10 and 8 h (). As shown in Figure b, the absorbance of MB decreased immediately after reaction (~30 min), but the rate for decomposition was almost similar after prolonged irradiation. This observance was consistent with those reported in the literature, in which the rate for the decomposition of MB was reported to be fast in the beginning and then slow in later time. Thus the absorbance of MB onto the coordination polymers could be ruled out. It is noted that the pure tpcb, 1,4-H2ndc, and 2,3-H2ndc ligands had no evident photocatalytic activity and only caused a slight fading of the MO or MB solution, which may be due to the self-degradation mentioned above. The final colorless solution was extracted by acetic ether, and the organic phase was analyzed by gas-chromatography (GC). No organic species was observed, and thus we could assume that all the dyes were converted into CO2 and H2O.

elements.content: The possible photocatalytic mechanism for the above degradation reactions is proposed as follows. During irradiation under UV light, electrons (e–) in the valence band (VB) were excited to the conduction band (CB), and holes (h+) were left in the VB. Then O2 was reduced into O2 – by the combination of electrons (e–), which further turned into hydroxyl radicals (·OH). At the same time, interaction of holes (h+) with hydroxyl (OH–) may produce a hydroxyl radical (·OH). Such a hydroxyl radical (·OH) is known to have high activity to destroy the organic dyes. The generation of hydroxyl radicals was demonstrated by hydroxylating 4-hydroxybenzoic acid into 2,4-dihydroxybenzoic acid. In this case, we took catalyst 2 as an example. When 2 was added into the 4-hydroxybenzoic acid aqueous solution, the mixture was then irradiated by UV light and the characteristic absorption band (215 nm) of 4-hydroxybenzoic acid gradually shifted to 295 nm (), which was the characteristic absorption band of 2,4-dihydroxybenzoic acid. This result suggested that the resulting hydroxyl radicals were captured by 4-hydroxybenzoic acid to form 2,4-dihydroxybenzoic acid. The photocatalytic efficiencies (3 > 2 > 1) may be because the energy gap between the UV light (wavelength = 365 nm, hν = 3.40 eV) and the coordination polymer (for 1, E g = 2.62 eV; for 2, E g = 2.90 eV; for 3, E g = 3.34 eV) decreases from 1 (0.78 eV) to 2 (0.50 eV) to 3 (0.06 eV). Such decreases may lead to the faster generation speed of hydroxyl radicals in 3 and the faster decomposition of MO or MB initiated by 3.

During irradiation under UV light, electrons (e-) in the valence band (VB) were excited to the conduction band (CB), and holes (h+) were left in the VB. Then O2 was reduced into O2 - by the combination of electrons (e-), which further turned into hydroxyl radicals (⋅OH). At the same time, interaction of holes (h+) with hydroxyl (OH-) may produce a hydroxyl radical (⋅OH). Such a hydroxyl radical (⋅OH) is known to have high activity to destroy the organic dyes. The generation of hydroxyl radicals was demonstrated by hydroxylating 4-hydroxybenzoic acid into 2,4-dihydroxybenzoic acid. In this case, we took catalyst 2 as an example. When 2 was added into the 4-hydroxybenzoic acid aqueous solution, the mixture was then irradiated by UV light and the characteristic absorption band (215 nm) of 4-hydroxybenzoic acid gradually shifted to 295 nm (), which was the characteristic absorption band of 2,4-dihydroxybenzoic acid. This result suggested that the resulting hydroxyl radicals were captured by 4-hydroxybenzoic acid to form 2,4-dihydroxybenzoic acid. The photocatalytic efficiencies (3 > 2 > 1) may be because the energy gap between the UV light (wavelength = 365 nm, hν = 3.40 eV) and the coordination polymer (for 1, E g = 2.62 eV; for 2, E g = 2.90 eV; for 3, E g = 3.34 eV) decreases from 1 (0.78 eV) to 2 (0.50 eV) to 3 (0.06 eV). Such decreases may lead to the faster generation speed of hydroxyl radicals in 3 and the faster decomposition of MO or MB initiated by 3.

elements.content: In this paper, we have demonstrated the formation of three different coordination polymers 1–3 from the solvent-dependent solvothermal reactions of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O with tpcb and 1,4-H2ndc or 2,3-H2ndc. It is noted that structural diversities of these frameworks may be also affected by the tpcb and 1,4-ndc or 2,3-ndc ligands. The four pyridyl groups of each tpcb ligand in 1–3 adopts an up–down–up–down conformation (Scheme ) but with different dihedral angles between the two opposite pyridyl groups. The tpcb ligand in 1–3 works as a three-connecting node (1 and 3) or a four-connecting node (2). In 1 and 2, the two carboxyl groups of the 1,4-ndc ligands show three different coordination modes: monodentate/monodentate, and monodentate/chelating (1), and chelating/chelating coordination (2). In 3, the two carboxyl groups of the 2,3-ndc ligands exhibit two different coordination modes: monodentate/monodentate and η,η-μ-bridging/η,η-μ-bridging. The thermal, photoluminescent and optical properties of 1–3 were also examined. Furthermore, the photocatalytic activities of 1–3 were evaluated by the decomposition of two organic dyes (MO and MB) in aqueous solution. It was found that the photocatalytic decomposition of MO and MB catalyzed by 3 was faster than those initiated by 1 and 2. The better catalytic performance of 3 may be ascribed to the smaller energy gap between the UV light and 3 and the faster generation speed of hydroxyl radicals. These results showed that reactions of Zn(II) ions with tpcb and dicarboxylates did afford new polydimensional frameworks (1–3), which are totally different from those derived from the similar reactions of Ni(II) or Cd(II) with tpcb and dicarboxylates. It is expected that such a solvent-dependent synthetic strategy may be applicable to other systems containing tpcb/polycarboxylate ligands to produce other multidimensional coordination polymers with new topological structures and better photocatalytic performances in decomposing organic dyes in polluted water. Studies on this respect are under way in this laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this paper, we have demonstrated the formation of three different coordination polymers 1-3 from the solvent-dependent solvothermal reactions of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O with tpcb and 1,4-H2ndc or 2,3-H2ndc. It is noted that structural diversities of these frameworks may be also affected by the tpcb and 1,4-ndc or 2,3-ndc ligands. The four pyridyl groups of each tpcb ligand in 1-3 adopts an up-down-up-down conformation (Scheme ) but with different dihedral angles between the two opposite pyridyl groups. The tpcb ligand in 1-3 works as a three-connecting node (1 and 3) or a four-connecting node (2). In 1 and 2, the two carboxyl groups of the 1,4-ndc ligands show three different coordination modes: monodentate/monodentate, and monodentate/chelating (1), and chelating/chelating coordination (2). In 3, the two carboxyl groups of the 2,3-ndc ligands exhibit two different coordination modes: monodentate/monodentate and η,η-μ-bridging/η,η-μ-bridging. The thermal, photoluminescent and optical properties of 1-3 were also examined. Furthermore, the photocatalytic activities of 1-3 were evaluated by the decomposition of two organic dyes (MO and MB) in aqueous solution. It was found that the photocatalytic decomposition of MO and MB catalyzed by 3 was faster than those initiated by 1 and 2. The better catalytic performance of 3 may be ascribed to the smaller energy gap between the UV light and 3 and the faster generation speed of hydroxyl radicals. These results showed that reactions of Zn(II) ions with tpcb and dicarboxylates did afford new polydimensional frameworks (1-3), which are totally different from those derived from the similar reactions of Ni(II) or Cd(II) with tpcb and dicarboxylates. It is expected that such a solvent-dependent synthetic strategy may be applicable to other systems containing tpcb/polycarboxylate ligands to produce other multidimensional coordination polymers with new topological structures and better photocatalytic performances in decomposing organic dyes in polluted water. Studies on this respect are under way in this laboratory.

elements.content: The ligand tpcb was prepared according to the literature method. Other chemicals and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Carlo-Erba CHNO-S microanalyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Varian Scamiter-1000 spectrometer (4000–400 cm–1). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out on a PANalytical X’Pert PRO MPD system (PW3040/60). Thermal analysis was performed with a Perkin-Elmer TGA-7 thermogravimetric analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min and a flow rate of 100 cm3/min (N2). The photoluminescent spectra were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer LS55 spectrofluorometer. Solid-state UV–vis–NIR spectra were measured with a Shimadzu UV-3150 spectrometer at room temperature in the range 200–700 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

The ligand tpcb was prepared according to the literature method. Other chemicals and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Carlo-Erba CHNO-S microanalyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Varian Scamiter-1000 spectrometer (4000-400 cm-1). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out on a PANalytical X'Pert PRO MPD system (PW3040/60). Thermal analysis was performed with a Perkin-Elmer TGA-7 thermogravimetric analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min and a flow rate of 100 cm3/min (N2). The photoluminescent spectra were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer LS55 spectrofluorometer. Solid-state UV-vis-NIR spectra were measured with a Shimadzu UV-3150 spectrometer at room temperature in the range 200-700 nm.

elements.content: To a 10 mL Pyrex glass tube was loaded Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,4-H2ndc (22 mg, 0.1 mmol), tpcb (18 mg, 0.05 mmol), 2.5 mL of H2O, and 0.5 mL of DMF. elements.content: Single crystals of 1–3 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly from the above preparations. The measurements of 1 and 3 were made on a Xcalibur, Atlas, Gemini diffractometer by using Enhance X-ray Source Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å), while the measurements of 2 were made by using Enhanced X-ray Source Cu Kα (λ = 1.54178 Å) due to the weak diffraction of the crystals. The crystals were mounted on glass fibers at 298 K for 2, and 223 K for 1 and 3. Cell parameters were refined by using the program CrysAlisPro, Agilent Technologies (Version 1.171.36.28). The collected data were reduced by using the program CrysAlisPro, and absorption corrections (multiscan) were applied. The reflection data was also corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determinations

Single crystals of 1-3 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly from the above preparations. The measurements of 1 and 3 were made on a Xcalibur, Atlas, Gemini diffractometer by using Enhance X-ray Source Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å), while the measurements of 2 were made by using Enhanced X-ray Source Cu Kα (λ = 1.54178 Å) due to the weak diffraction of the crystals. The crystals were mounted on glass fibers at 298 K for 2, and 223 K for 1 and 3. Cell parameters were refined by using the program CrysAlisPro, Agilent Technologies (Version 1.171.36.28). The collected data were reduced by using the program CrysAlisPro, and absorption corrections (multiscan) were applied. The reflection data was also corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects.

elements.content: The crystal structures of 1–3 were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods with the SHELXL-97 program. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms of the water solvent molecules in 1 and 3 were located from the Fourier map with the O–H distances being fixed at 0.82 Å. All other hydrogen atoms were placed in the geometrically idealized positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. Important crystal data and collection and refinement parameters for 1–3 are given in Table .

The photocatalytic activities of the samples were evaluated by the degradation of methyl orange (MO) and methyl blue (MB) in aqueous solution. A 50 mL of MO aqueous solution with a concentration of 0.1 g·L–1 or a 50 mL of MB aqueous solution with a concentration of 0.5 g·L–1 was mixed with 10 mg of the catalysts, respectively. A lamp (365 nm) was used as the UV resource. During the degradation, the mixture was stirred continuously by a magnetic stirrer. At regular time intervals, a 1 mL solution was sampled, filtered, and diluted to 10 mL in a volumetric flask. The UV–vis absorption spectra of MO or MB aqueous solutions were measured by a Hitachi U-4100 spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Activity Study

The photocatalytic activities of the samples were evaluated by the degradation of methyl orange (MO) and methyl blue (MB) in aqueous solution. A 50 mL of MO aqueous solution with a concentration of 0.1 g⋅L-1 or a 50 mL of MB aqueous solution with a concentration of 0.5 g⋅L-1 was mixed with 10 mg of the catalysts, respectively. A lamp (365 nm) was used as the UV resource. During the degradation, the mixture was stirred continuously by a magnetic stirrer. At regular time intervals, a 1 mL solution was sampled, filtered, and diluted to 10 mL in a volumetric flask. The UV-vis absorption spectra of MO or MB aqueous solutions were measured by a Hitachi U-4100 spectrophotometer.

elements.content: The experiment to demonstrate the generation of hydroxyl radical during the degradation catalyzed by 1–3 was carried out according to the literature method. A 50 mL of 4-hydroxybenzoic acid aqueous solution with a concentration of 5 mg·L–1 was mixed with 5 mg of the catalyst, and the mixture was stirred continuously by a magnetic stirrer. At regular time intervals (5 min, 10 min, 15 min), a 2 mL solution was sampled, and its UV–vis absorption spectra was measured by a Hitachi U-4100 spectrophotometer.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal stability of 1–3 was studied by the thermogravimetric differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) technique. The thermogravimetric analyses revealed that 1–3 were stable up to 353 °C (1), 352 °C (2), and 357 °C (3) (). For 1 and 3, the first weight loss of 1.90% from 25 to 81 °C (1) or 2.01% from 25 to 46 °C (3) corresponds roughly to the loss of one coordinated water molecule per formula unit in 1 and 3 (both calculated 1.91%). The second weight loss of 78.65% from 353 to 435 °C (1) or 79.53% from 357 to 424 °C (3) approximately amounts to the loss of all tpcb and naphthalenedicarboxylate ligands (both calculated 80.88%). For 2, only one weight loss of 82.45% from 357 to 615 °C amounts roughly to the loss of tpcb and 1,4-ndc ligands (calculated 82.42%). In all cases, the decomposition residue species, according to X-ray fluorescence analysis, was assumed to be ZnO (19.45% vs calculated 17.36% (1), 17.55% vs calculated 17.53% (2), and 18.46% vs calculated 17.36% (3)).

The photoluminescent properties of 1–3 in the solid state were studied at room temperature (Figure ). Upon excitation at 300 nm (1 and 2) and 370 nm (3), 1–3 exhibited photoluminescence with emission maxima at 450 nm (1), 410 nm (2), and 460 nm, respectively. The maximum emission wavelength for tpcb (λex = 330 nm) appears at 428 nm. Thus the emission maxima of 1 and 3 are slightly blue-shifted, which may be tentatively assigned to the π–π* intraligand fluorescence due to their close resemblance to the emission band of the tpcb ligand. Intriguingly, relative to that of the tpcb ligand, the emission peak of 2 is red-shifted ligand, which may be ascribed to the charge-transfer transitions between the coordinated ligands and the Zn(II) centers.

Thermal and Photoluminescent Properties

The thermal stability of 1-3 was studied by the thermogravimetric differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) technique. The thermogravimetric analyses revealed that 1-3 were stable up to 353 °C (1), 352 °C (2), and 357 °C (3) (). For 1 and 3, the first weight loss of 1.90% from 25 to 81 °C (1) or 2.01% from 25 to 46 °C (3) corresponds roughly to the loss of one coordinated water molecule per formula unit in 1 and 3 (both calculated 1.91%). The second weight loss of 78.65% from 353 to 435 °C (1) or 79.53% from 357 to 424 °C (3) approximately amounts to the loss of all tpcb and naphthalenedicarboxylate ligands (both calculated 80.88%). For 2, only one weight loss of 82.45% from 357 to 615 °C amounts roughly to the loss of tpcb and 1,4-ndc ligands (calculated 82.42%). In all cases, the decomposition residue species, according to X-ray fluorescence analysis, was assumed to be ZnO (19.45% vs calculated 17.36% (1), 17.55% vs calculated 17.53% (2), and 18.46% vs calculated 17.36% (3)).

The photoluminescent properties of 1-3 in the solid state were studied at room temperature (Figure ). Upon excitation at 300 nm (1 and 2) and 370 nm (3), 1-3 exhibited photoluminescence with emission maxima at 450 nm (1), 410 nm (2), and 460 nm, respectively. The maximum emission wavelength for tpcb (λex = 330 nm) appears at 428 nm. Thus the emission maxima of 1 and 3 are slightly blue-shifted, which may be tentatively assigned to the π-π* intraligand fluorescence due to their close resemblance to the emission band of the tpcb ligand. Intriguingly, relative to that of the tpcb ligand, the emission peak of 2 is red-shifted ligand, which may be ascribed to the charge-transfer transitions between the coordinated ligands and the Zn(II) centers.

GOF = {Σw((F o 2 – F c 2)2)/(n – p)}1/2, where n = number of reflections and p = total numbers of parameters refined.
